meanings.definition: To make something old-fashioned or outdated.
meanings.sent1: She decided to archaise her wardrobe by wearing vintage dresses.
meanings.sent2: The museum curator archaised the exhibit to give it a historical feel.
meanings.sent3: The students archaised their school project by using sepia tones in the presentation.
meanings.sent4: The antique shop owner archaised the store with retro signage.
meanings.sent5: The interior designer archaised the living room with classic furniture and decor.

meanings.definition: To use archaic language or style.
meanings.sent1: The author chose to archaise his writing to match the setting of the historical novel.
meanings.sent2: The playwright decided to archaise the dialogue to create a sense of authenticity.
meanings.sent3: The teacher playfully archaised her speech by using Shakespearean phrases in class.
meanings.sent4: The poet's work archaised the reader into a bygone era of romanticism.
meanings.sent5: The speech archaised the audience with its formal and outdated expressions.

meanings.definition: To imitate or mimic something from the past.
meanings.sent1: The artist sought to archaise the painting style of the Renaissance masters.
meanings.sent2: The actor tried to archaise the gestures and mannerisms of silent film stars.
meanings.sent3: The chef playfully archaised the recipe by cooking it in a traditional clay pot.
meanings.sent4: The fashion designer's collection archaised the glamour of old Hollywood.
meanings.sent5: The musician's new song archaised the melodies of 1950s rock and roll.
